content.title: Gangrene (Ischemic Tissue Necrosis)
content.definition: Death of body tissue due to insufficient blood supply (ischemia) or infection, representing the most severe manifestation of peripheral arterial disease. Classified as dry gangrene (mummification without infection) or wet gangrene (necrosis with superimposed infection).

key_concepts.description: Ischemic necrosis with tissue desiccation and mummification; well-demarcated margins between viable and nonviable tissue; typically not infected; may auto-amputate if limited and left untreated
Ischemic necrosis with superimposed bacterial infection; edema, purulence, foul odor; indistinct margins; systemic toxicity; requires urgent debridement/amputation and antibiotics
Rapidly progressive myonecrosis caused by Clostridium species (especially C. perfringens); crepitus, bronze discoloration, systemic toxicity; surgical emergency with high mortality
Gangrene = Fontaine Stage IV, Rutherford Category 5 (minor tissue loss) or 6 (major tissue loss); defines critical limb-threatening ischemia requiring revascularization
Clear line between gangrenous and viable tissue develops over 1-3 weeks in dry gangrene; allows for definitive amputation level selection. Wet gangrene lacks clear demarcation requiring wider margins
Minor = limited to digits, transmetatarsal level; potentially salvageable with revascularization. Major = extends beyond forefoot, may require below-knee or above-knee amputation
Goal is to revascularize to allow healing at the most distal amputation level possible; tissue loss alone is not contraindication to intervention if proximal tissue is viable
Wound-Ischemia-foot Infection staging system grades each component 0-3; guides amputation risk and revascularization benefit; high wound and ischemia grades need revascularization first
Neuropathy masks pain; minor trauma leads to ulceration and gangrene; infection spreads rapidly in immunocompromised tissue; requires aggressive debridement and off-loading

Wet gangrene: urgent source control (debridement/amputation), IV antibiotics. Dry gangrene: allow demarcation, revascularization assessment, minimize amputation level. Both: optimize medical comorbidities

learning_objectives: Distinguish dry gangrene from wet gangrene and their management implications
Recognize gas gangrene as a surgical emergency
Understand the role of revascularization in limb salvage
Apply WIfI classification for risk stratification
clinical_pearls: Dry gangrene: wait for demarcation, consider revascularization, minimize amputation
Wet gangrene: urgent debridement, can't wait for demarcation
Gas gangrene: crepitus + bronze skin + shock = immediate OR
Revascularize to save proximal tissue even if toe amputation needed
Neuropathic patients may have painless gangrene - always examine diabetic feet
WIfI high ischemia score = revascularize before debridement if possible
common_mistakes: Debriding dry gangrene before revascularization (wound won't heal)
Delaying debridement of wet gangrene for demarcation
Missing gas gangrene - always palpate for crepitus
Amputating too proximal without revascularization assessment
Ignoring asymptomatic gangrene in diabetic neuropathy
